msDesc.head: Letter from Mary Russell Mitford to Mary Webb, February 4, 1820. Letter dated Friday night. We arrived at this date by checking a perpetual calendar and Mitford's journal.

support.p: One 10.3 mm x 16.8 mm sheet of paper, two surfaces photographed. Folded in half vertically once.

condition.p: Sheet has darkened spots and semi-circles, perhaps caused by water damage.

handNotes.handNote: Someone, apparently other than Mitford, perhaps cataloging letters and describing them, who left grey pencil marks and numbered her letters now in the Reading Central Library's collection. This letter labeled [4 Feb. 1820].

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

div.p:
We rejoiced very much to hear of dear Eliza's amendment--she is the best good girl in all the world to do as we bid her & take care of herself--she "will live to dance another day" in consequence--for I assure you Papa was frightened about her.--We have heard a good account of your dear Father today--Poor Papa after a solitary coursing at Sonning--Mr. Charles Symonds & had the mortification to find that a party had been out in the Neighborhood--Mr. Webb at the head
of them--whom he would have been delighted to have joined. Mr. Symonds said that your father expected him & had sent him word on Tuesday--but as he never heard of it til today after the coursing was over your Father must have employed a faithless messenger--Pray how did Mr. Webb send his information? I have never heard from you my dear love since your note on Monday.--You were a goose to fancy I had been to Mortimer Common--the stifflegged sufferer in question was poor Papa--He & Wallace have been very unlucky--they went out three days & killed
three rabbits--not at all Wallace's fault who is very amiable--he takes to me very much--knocking me down & is a great favourite.--Deuce take these royal Dyings! We've been obliged to try a new bombazine--half ruined me! No the Mourning won't be longer than 4 months, so some of them may as well take the opportunity.--I had hoped to be able to see you this week my own dear friends & catch another glimpse of dear Mrs. Hayward & her sweet little ones especially that Maiden blush rose Miss Susan--but between gown buying--& rabbit killing Papa & We’ve been so engaged that we’ve not even been able to get to Mrs. Dickinson who sent me a summons last Monday.--We had an umbrella my own dear Mary--When were you ever inattentive? Never.--Kind love to all--
